Expectation1: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation1: An emergency diversion cuts across three sectors at once, requiring rapid multi-sector coordination.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story: The radar screen flickered with urgent blips as a passenger jet declared an emergency, its path slicing across three sectors. My headset crackled with voices—sector leads, pilots, supervisors—each demanding split-second decisions to keep the airspace safe. I felt the weight of every life in the sky pressing on my shoulders. Suddenly, the building’s flood alarm blared, and a message flashed on my phone: “Flash-flood warning. Evacuate immediately.” I glanced out the window; water was already pooling in the parking lot, swirling around cars. As a citizen, I knew I should help neighbors, alert others, and get to safety. But as an air traffic controller, I couldn’t abandon my post—not with lives depending on my coordination. My heart pounded, torn between the duty to my community and the responsibility to the skies. The voices in my headset grew more urgent, but so did the sirens outside. I gripped the console, paralyzed by the impossible choice.
